{{distinguish|liberal conservatism|conservative liberalism}} {{Conservatism US |Schools}} {{Libertarianism in the United States sidebar|Related}} '''Libertarian conservatism''' or '''conservative libertarianism''' is a [[political philosophy]] and [[ideology]] that combines [[Right-libertarianism|right-libertarian]] [[politics]] and [[Conservatism|conservative values]]. Libertarian conservatism advocates the greatest possible economic liberty and the least possible government regulation of social life, mirroring ''[[laissez faire|laissez-faire]]'' [[classical liberalism|liberalism]], but harnesses this to a belief in a more traditional and conservative social philosophy emphasizing authority and duty.{{sfn|Heywood|2015|p=37}} Libertarian conservatism prioritizes [[liberty]] as its main emphasis, promoting [[free expression]], [[freedom of choice]] and [[free market capitalism]] to achieve [[Social conservatism|socially]] and [[Cultural conservatism|culturally conservative]] ends as they reject [[Modern liberalism in the United States|liberal]] [[Social engineering (political science)|social engineering]],<ref name=Piper>J. Richard Piper, ''Ideologies and Institutions: American Conservative and Liberal Governance Prescriptions Since 1933'', [[Rowman & Littlefield]], 1997, [https://books.google.com/books?id=u93Mj3A-tH8C&pg=PA110 pp. 110–111], {{ISBN|0847684598}}, {{ISBN|978-0847684595}}.</ref> or in the opposite way but not excluding the above, libertarian conservatism could be understood as promoting [[civil society]] through conservative institutions and authority - as family, fatherland, religion, education - in the quest of libertarian ends for less state power.<ref>[https://mises.org/library/getting-libertarianism-right Getting Libertarianism Right]. [[Hans-Hermann Hoppe]]. {{ISBN|978-1-61016-690-4}}. [[Mises Institute]] Publishing.</ref>
== Philosophy == For Larry Johnston, in [[political science]], the term "libertarian conservatism" is used to refer to ideologies that combine the advocacy of economic principles such as [[fiscal discipline]], respect for [[contract]]s, defense of [[private property]] and [[free market]]s{{sfn|Johnston|2007|pp=154–56}} and the [[Traditionalist conservatism|traditional conservative]] stress on self-help and freedom of choice under a ''[[laissez-faire]]'' and [[Economic liberalism|economically liberal]] [[Capitalism|capitalist]] society with social tenets such as the importance of [[religion]] and the value of [[Religious morality|traditional morality]]{{sfn|Johnston|2007|p=154}} through a framework of [[Limited government|limited]], [[Constitutional government|constitutional]], [[representative government]].{{sfn|Johnston|2007|pp=154–155}}
For Margaret Randall, libertarian conservatism began as an expression of [[individualism]] and the demand for [[personal freedom]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Schlesinger|first=Arthur|authorlink=Arthur M. Schlesinger, Sr.|title=The Rise of the City: 1878-1898|publisher=The Academy of Political Science|date=September 1933|orig-year=1st pub. 1933|pages=454–456|chapter=Vol. 48}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Randall|first=Margaret|authorlink=Margaret Randall|title=Sandino's Daughters: Testimonies of Nicaraguan Women in Struggle|publisher=Rutgers University Press|date=January 14, 2018|orig-year=1st pub. 1995|pages=ii|chapter=Preface}}</ref>
''Freedom and Virtue: The Conservative/Libertarian Debate'', edited by George W. Carey, contains essays which describe "the tension between liberty and morality" as "the main fault line dividing the two philosophies".<ref>George W. Carey (Editor), ''Freedom & Virtue: The Conservative Libertarian Debate,'' Intercollegiate Studies Institute, 1998. {{ISBN|1-882926-19-6}}.</ref>
Nelson Hultberg wrote that there is "philosophical common ground" between libertarians and conservatives. "The true conservative movement was, from the start, a blend of political libertarianism, cultural conservatism, and non-interventionism abroad bequeathed to us via the Founding Fathers". He said that such libertarian conservatism was "hijacked" by [[neoconservatism]], "by the very enemies it was formed to fight – [[Fabian Society|Fabians]], [[New Deal]]ers, [[Welfare state|welfarists]], [[Progressivism in the United States|progressives]], globalists, interventionists, militarists, nation builders, and all the rest of the collectivist ilk that was assiduously working to destroy the Founders' Republic of States".<ref>Nelson Hultberg, [http://www.afr.org/Hultberg/122006.html "True Conservatism vs. Neo-Conservatism"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080820085956/http://www.afr.org/Hultberg/122006.html|date=August 20, 2008}}, [http://afr.org "Americans for a Free Republic"] website, December 20, 2006.</ref>
[[Thomas DiLorenzo]] wrote that libertarian conservative [[Constitutionalism|constitutionalists]] believe that the way to limit government is to enforce the [[United States Constitution]]. However, DiLorenzo criticized them by writing: "The fatal flaw in the thinking of the libertarian/conservative constitutionalists stems from their unawareness or willful ignorance of how the founders themselves believed the Constitution could be enforced: by the citizens of the free, independent, and sovereign states, not the federal judiciary". He wrote that the powers accrued to the federal government during the [[American Civil War]] overthrew the Constitution of 1787.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://archive.lewrockwell.com/dilorenzo/dilorenzo74.html|title=Constitutional Futility|last=DiLorenzo|first=Thomas|publisher=LewRockwell.com|accessdate=July 2, 2008}}</ref>
In the 1950's [[Frank Meyer (political philosopher)|Frank Meyer]], a prominent contributor to the ''[[National Review]]'', called his own combination libertarianism and conservatism as "[[fusionism]]".<ref name="Feser">Edward Feser, [http://archive.lewrockwell.com/orig/feser2.html "What Libertarianism Isn't"], [[Lew Rockwell.com]], December 22, 2001.</ref><ref>Ralph Raico, [https://mises.org/story/1784 "Is Libertarianism Amoral?"], ''New Individualist Review'', Volume 3, Number 3, Fall 1964, 29–36; republished by [[Ludwig von Mises Institute]], April 4, 2005.</ref>
In the 1990s, [[Lew Rockwell]], [[Murray Rothbard]] and others described their libertarian conservative views as [[paleolibertarianism]].<ref name=LR>{{cite journal|last1=Rockwell|first1=Lew|title=The Case for Paleo-libertarianism|journal=Liberty|issue=January 1990|pages=34–38|url=http://www.pericles.press/wp-content/uploads/2016/11/Liberty_Magazine.pdf}}.</ref> They continued libertarian opposition to "all forms of government intervention – economic, cultural, social, international", but also upholding cultural conservatism in social thought and behavior. They opposed a licentious libertarianism which advocated "freedom from bourgeois morality, and social authority".<ref name=LR/> Rockwell later stated that they dropped that self-description because people confused it with [[paleoconservatism]], which they rejected.<ref name=lewinterview>{{cite web|url=http://archive.lewrockwell.com/rockwell/liberal-post-interview.html|title=Do You Consider Yourself a Libertarian?|last=Johnsson|first=Kenny|publisher=LewRockwell.com|accessdate=July 2, 2008}}</ref><ref name=lrc>{{cite web|url=http://archive.lewrockwell.com/rockwell/paleoism.html|title=What I Learned From Paleoism|last=Rockwell|first=Llewellyn H.|publisher=LewRockwell.com|accessdate=July 2, 2008}}</ref>
Laurence M. Vance wrote: "Some libertarians consider libertarianism to be a lifestyle rather than a political philosophy... They apparently don't know the difference between libertarianism and [[libertinism]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://archive.lewrockwell.com/vance/vance133.html|title=Is Ron Paul Wrong on Abortion?|last=Vance|first=Laurence|date=January 29, 2008|publisher=LewRockwell.com|accessdate=July 1, 2008}}</ref>
[[Friedrich Hayek]], [[Ludwig von Mises]], [[Milton Friedman]], [[Richard Posner]], [[Richard Epstein]] and [[Albert Jay Nock]] have been described as libertarian conservatives.<ref name=Piper/><ref>[https://mises.org/library/cultural-thought-ludwig-von-mises-0 Cultural Thought of Ludwig von Mises]. [[Journal of Libertarian Studies]]. 1991. Lew Rockwell and Jeffrey Tucker. Mises Institute.</ref> Former [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. Congressman]] [[Ron Paul]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://archive.lewrockwell.com/orig8/mafaldo1.html|title=The Conservative Case for Ron Paul|last=Mafaldo|first=Lucas|publisher=LewRockwell.com|accessdate=July 2, 2008}}{{dead link|date=December 2017|bot=InternetArchiveBot|fix-attempted=yes}}</ref> and his son [[United States Senate|U.S. Senator]] [[Rand Paul]] have been described as combining libertarian and conservative "[[small government]]" ideas and showing how the Constitution defends the individual and most libertarian views.
In 1975, [[Ronald Reagan]] stated: "I believe the very heart and soul of conservatism is libertarianism". However, some libertarians criticized Reagan for un-libertarian policy positions.<ref>[http://www.reason.com/news/show/29318.html "Inside Ronald Reagan"], a ''[[Reason (magazine)|Reason]]'' interview with Ronald Reagan, July 1975.</ref>
[[Edward Feser]] emphasized that libertarianism does not require individuals to reject traditional conservative values. Libertarianism supports the ideas of [[liberty]], [[privacy]] and ending the [[War on drugs|war on marijuana]] at the legal level without changing personal values.<ref name="Feser"/>
=== Economics === Libertarian conservatism subscribes to the libertarian idea of [[free market capitalism]], advocating minimal to no government interference in the [[Market (economics)|market]]. A number of libertarian conservatives favor [[Austrian economics]] and are critical of [[fiat money]], with many supporting policies like [[pay what you want]] cafes. Libertarian conservatives also advocate for ways to [[Privatization|privatize]] services run by the government, from airports to toll booths.

In politics, a '''martyr''' is someone who suffers persecution and/or death for advocating, renouncing, refusing to renounce, and/or refusing to advocate a political belief or cause.
The [[Manchester Martyrs]] were three Irishmen executed after being condemned for association with the killing of a policeman in [[Manchester]], England in 1867. The day after the executions, [[Frederick Engels]] wrote to [[Karl Marx]]: "Yesterday morning the Tories, by the hand of Mr Calcraft, accomplished the final act of separation between England and Ireland. The only thing that the [[Fenians]] still lacked were martyrs. ... To my knowledge, the only time that anybody has been executed for a similar matter in a civilised country was the case of [[John Brown (abolitionist)|John Brown]] at Harpers Ferry. The Fenians could not have wished for a better precedent."<ref>Marx and Engels in Ireland (1971) Progress Publishers, Moscow. [http://www.marxists.org/archive/marx/works/1867/letters/67_11_24.htm Letter of November 24 1867 Engels to Marx]</ref>
The [[Tolpuddle Martyrs]] were a group of 19th century agricultural labourers in [[Dorset]], England, who were arrested for and convicted of swearing a secret oath as members of the ''Friendly Society of Agricultural Labourers.'' The rules of the society showed it was clearly structured as a [[friendly society]], that is, a mutual association for the purposes of insurance, pensions, savings or cooperative banking; and it operated as a trade-specific [[benefit society]]. But at the time, friendly societies had strong elements of what are now considered to be the principal role of [[trade union]]s, and wages were at issue. The Tolpuddle Martyrs were sentenced not to death but to [[penal transportation|transportation]] to [[Australia]], a harsh form of exile.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.historic-uk.com/HistoryUK/England-History/TolpuddleMartyrs.htm |title=The Tolpuddle Martyrs |publisher=Historic-uk.com |date= |accessdate=2014-08-22}}</ref>
The [[Belfiore martyrs]] (in [[italian language|Italian]], ''Martiri di Belfiore'') were a group of [[Italy|Italian]] pro-independence fighters condemned to death by hanging in 1853 during the Italian Risorgimento. They included [[Tito Speri]] and the priest [[Enrico Tazzoli (priest)|Enrico Tazzoli]] and are named after the site where the sentence was carried out, in the valley of Belfiore at the south entrance to [[Mantua]].
Many [[communist]] activists have died as martyrs in India, due to their allegiance to various communist parties, such as the [[Communist Party of India (Marxist)|CPI(M)]] and the [[Communist Party of India|CPI]]. Most of them hail from mainly [[leftist]] states such as [[Kerala]], and [[Tripura]]. In Kerala, many are killed in protests by the police, and some are assassinated by activists in other political parties, such as the [[Indian National Congress|INC]] and the [[Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh|RSS]]. The district of [[Kannur district|Kannur]] has reported to have had the most political murders. Here, the RSS are known to have used brutal violence to eliminate CPI(M) workers.
Other notable martyrs include: * 1965 – [[Malcolm X]], assassinated due to his leadership in [[Black Nationalism]] * 1968 – [[Martin Luther King Jr.]], assassinated for his leadership of the [[Civil Rights Movement]] * 1981 – [[Bobby Sands]], an Irish Republican who died on hunger strike while imprisoned

{{Refimprove|date=March 2010}} '''Minoritarianism''' is a [[neologism]] for a political structure or process in which a minority segment of a population has a certain degree of primacy in that entity's [[decision making]]. https://www.livemint.com/Opinion/Fhu5gJzl3u4LwuErXoJxFO/Majority-minority-authority.html Minoritarianism may be contrasted with [[majoritarianism]], but with legislative power being held or controlled by a minority group rather than the majority. ==Concept in depth== Minoritarianism is most often applied disparagingly to processes in which a minority is able to block legislative changes through [[supermajority]] threshold requirements. For example, if a 2/3 vote in favor is required to enact a new law, a minority of greater than 1/3 is said to have "minoritarian" powers. Even in the case where minority control is nominally limited to blocking the majority with [[veto]] power (whether as a result of a supermajority requirement or a consensus process), this may result in the situation where the minority retains effective control over the group's agenda and the nature of the proposals submitted to the group, as the majority will not propose ideas that they know the minority will veto. Critics of this use of ''minoritarianism'' argue that the ability to block legislation is substantially different from the ability to enact new legislation against the will of the majority, making the analogy to unpopular "dominant minority rule" examples inappropriate. Minoritarianism is sometimes used to describe rule by a [[dominant minority]] such as an [[ethnic group]] delineated by [[religion]], [[language]] or some other identifying factor. Historical examples included [[Rhodesia]] (now called [[Zimbabwe]]) under [[Ian Smith]] and [[South Africa under apartheid]] rule and some would say after apartheid rule.http://johnpilger.com/articles/south-africa-20-years-of-apartheid-by-another-name [[John Pilger]] Apartheid by another name Minoritarianism may also be used to describe some cases where appeasement of [[minorities]] by [[Votebank|votebank politics]] is practiced. Examples include, but are not limited to, Indian Muslims, Jewish Americans, and Francophone Canadians. ==In small deliberative groups== Supermajority decision threshold requirements are often found in small deliberative groups where these requirements are sometimes adopted in an attempt to increase protection of varied interests within the group. The requirements may be formally stated or may be unstated (for example, when an organization is described as having a "consensus culture"). A common criticism of [[consensus decision-making]] is that it can lead to a situation wherein a minority can block the will of the majority. Consensus advocates argue that this is a good feature—that ''no action'' is preferable to one without the consensus support of the group. Attempts to resolve the dilemma through formal supermajority standards are generally discouraged by parliamentary authorities:
Some people have mistakenly assumed that the higher the vote required to take an action, the greater the protection of the members. Instead the opposite is true. Whenever a vote of more than a majority is required to take an action, control is taken from the majority and given to the minority. ... The higher the vote required, the smaller the minority to which control passes.
— from "The Standard Code of Parliamentary Procedure" by [[Alice Sturgis]]https://books.google.co.in/books?id=5THFbCnDdbIC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2012}} {{Gaza blockade}} '''National reactions to the Gaza flotilla raid''' on 31 May 2010 ranged from ranged from support to strong condemnation of Israel. Those supporting Israel generally also expressed concern for the loss of life and injuries to civilians. Criticism included the death and injuries of civilians, the disproportionate response, and the execution of the raid.
== Israel == {{flagicon|Israel}} [[Israeli Prime Minister]] [[Benjamin Netanyahu]], who was in Canada during the incident, expressed regret for the loss of life, and said that the event represents a clear case of self-defense of the IDF soldiers,<ref name="Netanyahu">{{cite press release|url=http://www.pmo.gov.il/PMOEng/Communication/Spokesman/2010/06/spokehatshara010610.htm |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100605042336/http://www.pmo.gov.il/PMOEng/Communication/Spokesman/2010/06/spokehatshara010610.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date= 5 June 2010 |title=Statement by PM Netanyahu Regarding Flotilla to Gaza |publisher=Prime Minister's Office, Israel |date=1 June 2010 |accessdate=2 June 2010 |df= }}</ref><ref name="bloody">{{cite news|author=Steven Gutkin |date=31 May 2010 |title=Bloody Israeli raid on flotilla sparks crisis |url=http://www.newstimes.com/news/article/Israeli-army-At-least-4-killed-on-Gaza-flotilla-504846.php#page-1 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100603142615/http://www.newstimes.com/news/article/Israeli-army-At-least-4-killed-on-Gaza-flotilla-504846.php |dead-url=yes |archive-date= 3 June 2010 |agency=[[Associated Press]] |work=[[The News-Times]] |location=Danbury, Conn. |accessdate=2 June 2010 |df= }} </ref> he expressed his "full backing" for the military raid and cancelled a scheduled trip to the United States to meet with U.S. President [[Barack Obama]]. A spokesman for the Prime Minister was quoted as saying that Netanyahu, "feels he has to be home to deal with this".<ref name="wsj-world">{{Cite news |title=More Than 10 Dead After Israel Intercepts Gaza Aid Convoy |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703703704575277632709673018?mod=WSJ_hpp_LEADNewsCollection |date=31 May 2010 |work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |accessdate=31 May 2010 | first=Joshua | last=Mitnick}}</ref><ref name=hpgaza>{{Cite news |title=Gaza Flotilla ATTACKED: Israel Storms Aid Ship, 9 Dead |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/05/31/gaza-flotilla-attacked-israel_n_595239.html |date=31 May 2010 |publisher=[[The Huffington Post]] |accessdate=31 May 2010 |first=Nico |last=Pitney}}</ref> he told a press conference that had Israel not stopped the flotilla from breaking the blockade and entering the Gaza Strip illegally, hundreds of more flotillas would [[Gaza flotilla raid#Investigation for onboard weapons|arrive carrying weapons]].<ref>Sofer, Roni. [http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3898256,00.html "PM: I am proud of soldiers"]. [[Ynetnews]]. 2 June 2010. 2 June 2010.</ref> He stood his ground defending the raid and said Israel will never apologize for the incident.<ref>[http://www.presstv.ir/detail.aspx?id=128850&sectionid=351020202 "Israel will never apologize"]. [[Press TV]] (3 June 2010). {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100603032502/http://www.presstv.ir/detail.aspx?id=128850&sectionid=351020202 |date= 3 June 2010 }}</ref> In an address to the country, on 2 June he said "Israel faces hypocrisy and a biased rush to judgment."<ref>[https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601087&sid=adpD_NkddCS0&pos=9 "Israelis Support Netanyahu Charging Hypocrisy on Gaza (Update1)"]. [[Bloomberg News]] (4 June 2010).</ref> He further noted that in five of the six vessels in the flotilla, the boarding procedure ended without casualties. "The only difference was with one ship, where extremist Islamic activists, supporters of terrorism, waited for our troops on the deck with axes and knives."<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/jun/05/israel-rachel-corrie-gaza-ship "Israeli forces board the Rachel Corrie"], ''[[The Guardian]]'', 5 June 2010</ref>
After the boarding took place, Deputy Foreign Minister [[Danny Ayalon]] said that the flotilla of ships "was an armada of hate and violence". He added that the flotilla attempt to reach Gaza was "a premeditated and outrageous provocation" and claimed that its organizers had ties not only to [[Hamas]], but also to global [[Jihadism|Jihad]], and [[al Qaida]].<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.jpost.com/Israel/Article.aspx?id=176998 | newspaper=[[The Jerusalem Post]] | title=Barak: Flotilla organizers to blame | date=31 May 2010 | accessdate=2 June 2010}}</ref>
Israeli Foreign Minister [[Avigdor Lieberman]] called the international community "two faced" and said Israel was being condemned for its military acts of defense.<ref>{{cite news |last=Shamir |first=Shlomo |url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/diplomacy-defense/lieberman-to-un-chief-international-community-is-two-faced-for-condemning-israel-1.293299 |title=Lieberman to UN chief: International community is two-faced for condemning Israel |work=[[Haaretz]] |location=Israel |accessdate=12 May 2012}}</ref> Lieberman was said to have been "reminding" the UN Secretary General that in the past month alone over 500 people were killed in various incidents in Thailand, Afghanistan, Pakistan, Iraq and [[Indo-Israeli relations|India]], which had allegedly been "ignored" while Israel was being condemned for its "unmistakably defensive actions". Israel later rescinded its criticism of India.<ref>[http://www.deccanherald.com/content/73116/israel-drops-indias-name-list.html "Israel drops India's name from the list of violence hit nations"]. ''[[Deccan Herald]]''</ref>
Opposition leader [[Tzipi Livni]] said that the coalition and the opposition are united in support of the defense forces, and that she is ready to assist the government in the political and explanatory aspects of the flotilla incident.<ref>[http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3896557,00.html "Livni offers help: In defending IDF there is no coalition, opposition"]. [[Ynetnews]] (20 June 1995).</ref> She, however, disagreed with what she considered Netanyahu's lack of policy: "The world is certainly hypocritical, but that doesn't absolve us from forming a policy. This is more than an isolated incident. Anything that happened when Israel had a different standing in world opinion would have had a different result. Now, any isolated incident becomes a global drama, and it's becoming worse. We are reaching the stage when Israel's ability to defend itself will no longer exist." She said the lack of policy in the aftermath of the incident would jeopardize Israel's legitimacy and backing from the international community, which she says for years had insisted on not recognizing Hamas until it recognizes Israel and accepts past agreements, and had accepted the closure of Gaza while "it was clear that Israel wanted an agreement with pragmatic forces, with the legitimate Palestinian government." She also said that IDF soldiers acted appropriately, and supports setting up an internal investigation committee with the United States.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3898602,00.html |title=Livni: Keep world from investigating IDF soldiers |publisher=[[Ynetnews]] |date=20 June 1995 |accessdate=12 May 2012}}</ref>
Ambassador to the U.K., [[Ron Prosor]], said: "It's obvious – and I won't beat around the bush on this – that this wasn't successful and I think it clearly took up an issue that should have been solved differently." [However, the] other side [behaved] appallingly. [Israel was in a] war situation with terrorists. The loss of life was tragic and I’m not just saying that. When you look at the footage ... it's obvious that the reaction is self—defence to try and save your life."<ref>{{cite news|author=DPA |url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/international/article443610.ece |newspaper=[[The Hindu]] |title=Flotilla attack could have been 'solved differently,' says Israeli envoy |date=29 May 2010 |location=Chennai, India |accessdate=2 June 2010}}</ref>
The Israeli high court rejected a petition seeking to overrule Attorney-General [[Yehuda Weinstein]]'s decision to halt the police investigation into the attack.<ref>{{cite news |date=4 June 2010 |title=Court dismisses flotilla petitions |newspaper=[[The Jerusalem Post]] |url=http://www.jpost.com/Israel/Court-dismisses-flotilla-petitions}}</ref> On 3 June, the [[Israeli Supreme Court]] ruled that the soldiers responded in self-defense, and that the [[Gaza blockade]] and the raid of the ships were legal.<ref>Aviad Glickman,[http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3898429,00.html High Court rejects flotilla suits: Soldiers defended their lives], [[Ynetnews]] (English), 3 June 2010.</ref>
[[Strategic Affairs Minister of Israel|Minister of Strategic Affairs]] [[Moshe Ya'alon]], a former [[Chief of General Staff (Israel)|IDF chief of staff]], announced that the operation was a failure and instead of distributing citations Israel was busy trying to understand why basic operating protocol was not implemented.<ref>Yechiel Spira, [http://www.theyeshivaworld.com/news/Israeli+News/61601/IDF-Locked-Out-of-Planning-Session-Ahead-of-Mavi-Marmara.html "IDF Locked Out of Planning Session Ahead of Mavi Marmara"], [[Yeshiva World News]], 10 June 2010</ref>
== Turkey == [[File:CumhuriyetStatue-Palestine.jpg|thumb|Welcoming activists from Gaza in [[Istanbul]]'s [[Taksim Square]], on 2nd of June 2010 following the Gaza flotilla raid.]] {{flagicon|TUR}} Turkish Deputy Prime Minister, [[Bülent Arınç]] said "In the name of the Turkish people and of our government, we strongly condemn these attacks,"<ref name="arinc">{{cite news|title=Israel condemned after flotilla attack |work=[[Financial Times]]|date=31 May 2010|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/b09c57f6-6c80-11df-91c8-00144feab49a.html}}</ref> and he announced that Turkey canceled an U-19 football game against Israel.<ref name=haaretzfootball/> He added that no one should think that Turkey would declare war on Israel.<ref name="arıncwar">{{cite news|title=Arınç: Savaş açmamız beklenmesin – Dış Politika- |publisher=[[NTV (Turkey)|NTV MSNBC]]|date=31 May 2010|url=http://www.ntvmsnbc.com/id/25101418/}}</ref>
Prime Minister [[Recep Tayyip Erdoğan]] said that the raid was "state terror" and decided to return from a state visit to Chile.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSLDE64U1UF20100531 |title=Aid ship raid is Israeli state terrorism-Turkish PM |publisher=[[Reuters]] |date= 31 May 2010|accessdate=2 June 2010}}</ref> Erdoğan spoke to the [[Justice and Development Party (Turkey)|AKP]] Group at the [[Grand National Assembly of Turkey|Turkish Parliament]], he said "Turkey's friendship is as strong as its animosity."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3897404,00.html |title=Erdogan to Israel: Don't test our patience |publisher=[[Ynetnews]] |date=20 June 1995 |accessdate=12 May 2012}}</ref> He also strongly rebuked Israel's action saying even pirates had a code of conduct.<!--Source is from CNN International on TV, video seen of him saying that--> Erdoğan upped the ante, in a speech to legislators saying Israel should be "punished" for its "bloody massacre" amid a warning that no one should test Turkey's patience. He said "It is no longer possible to cover up or ignore Israel's lawlessness. The international community must from now on say 'enough is enough'. Dry statements of condemnation are not enough ... There should be results." He said the Israeli action was an attack "on international law, [and] the conscience of humanity and world peace". He even said that Israel acts as it does because it has powerful friends.<ref name="aljaz2"/> He called for Israel to lift the "inhuman siege" of the Gaza Strip, which he referred to as an "open-air prison", and announced that he was considering sending the [[Turkish Navy]] to escort any future flotillas or to visit Gaza himself, in order to break the blockade. He also urged the international community to impose sanctions on Israel.
President [[Abdullah Gül]] said, "From now on, Turkish-Israeli ties will never be the same. This incident has left an irreperable and deep scar." He also said, "Turkey will never forgive this attack."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/europe/2010/06/2010631253044379.html |title=AJE |publisher=[[Al Jazeera English]] |accessdate=12 May 2012 }}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Gül compared Israel's actions to those of [[al-Qaeda]], and demanded that Israel apologize and pay compensation, and also urged Israel to thoroughly investigate the incident and lift the blockade of Gaza.<ref>[http://www.almanar.com.lb/newssite/NewsDetails.aspx?id=141812&language=en] [[Al-Manar]]{{dead link|date=March 2011}}</ref>
A Turkish Foreign Ministry statement condemned Israel,<ref name=tel>{{cite news|last=Spencer |first=Richard |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/middleeast/israel/7789117/At-least-16-dead-as-Israeli-troops-storm-Gaza-aid-flotilla.html |title=At least 16 dead as Israeli troops storm Gaza aid flotilla |newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |date=31 May 2010 |location=London |accessdate=31 May 2010}}</ref> and the foreign ministry was reported to have summoned the Israeli ambassador to lodge a protest.<ref name="aljazeera1">{{cite news |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2010/05/201053133047995359.html |title=Israel attacks Gaza aid fleet |publisher=[[Al Jazeera English]] |date=31 May 2010 |accessdate=31 May 2010}}</ref> Turkey recalled its ambassador from Israel.<ref name="turkamb">{{cite news|title=Turkey withdraws ambassador to Israel over deaths|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=31 May 2010|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/05/31/AR2010053100985.html}} {{Dead link|date=August 2010|bot=RjwilmsiBot}}</ref> Foreign Minister, [[Ahmet Davutoğlu]] told the UN [[Security Council]] that Israel has "lost all legitimacy" as a result of the raid.<ref>{{cite news |author=Mohamad Shmaysani |url=http://www.almanar.com.lb/newssite/NewsDetails.aspx?id=139903&language=en |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100531202423/http://www.almanar.com.lb/NewsSite/NewsDetails.aspx?id=139903&language=en |dead-url=yes |archive-date=31 May 2010 |title=Turkish FM at U.N.S.C Meeting: Israel Has Lost International Legitimacy 31/05/2010 |publisher=Al-Manar |accessdate=2 June 2010}}</ref> He called those who died "[[Shahid|martyrs]]".<ref name="davutmar">{{cite news|title=Davutoğlu: İsrail’in yaptığı korsanlıktır |publisher=[[NTV (Turkey)|NTV MSNBC]] |date=31 May 2010|url=http://www.ntvmsnbc.com/id/25101298//}}</ref> He said, "It is no longer possible to cover up or ignore Israel's lawlessness. It is time for the international community to say 'enough is enough'." He also said that Turkey was ready to normalise ties if the blockade on Gaza was lifted because "it was time calm replaces anger." That, in turn, was accompanied with statement saying the injured would stay in Tel Aviv hospital under the care of a Turkish doctor, "We will not leave them (the wounded) to the mercy of anyone."<ref>[http://english.aljazeera.net/news/europe/2010/06/20106293939694105.html "Turkey demands return of citizens"]. [[Al Jazeera English]] (2 June 2010).</ref> The [[Parliament of Turkey]] unanimously adopted a resolution calling for the [[United Nations Security Council]] to impose sanctions on Israel, and called the attack a "blatant violation of the UN Charter and international law".<ref>{{cite web|author=John Pike |url=http://www.globalsecurity.org |title=Turkey calls for international sanctions on Israel |publisher=Globalsecurity.org |date=18 April 2012 |accessdate=12 May 2012}}</ref>
[[İlker Başbuğ]], [[Chief of the General Staff (Turkey)|Chief of the Turkish Armed Forces]] held a phone conversation with [[Gabi Ashkenazi]], the [[Chief of General Staff (Israel)|Israeli Chief of Staff]] and called the raid unacceptable and indicated such actions could hold very serious consequences.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tsk.tr/10_ARSIV/10_1_Basin_Yayin_Faaliyetleri/10_3_Bilgi_Notlari/2010/BN_55.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100602085241/http://www.tsk.tr/10_ARSIV/10_1_Basin_Yayin_Faaliyetleri/10_3_Bilgi_Notlari/2010/BN_55.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date= 2 June 2010 |title=Genelkurmay Başkanlığı Resmi Kurumsal İnternet Sitesidir – Anasayfa |publisher=Turkish Armed Force |accessdate=2 June 2010 |df= }}</ref> Turkey said that all future aid vessels would be escorted by the [[Turkish Navy]].<ref name="IBN Live">{{cite news |url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/turkey-threatens-action-israel-on-alert/116743-2.html?from=tn|title=Turkey threatens action; Israel on alert |publisher=[[IBN Live]] |date=31 May 2010 |accessdate=31 May 2010}}</ref>
Leaders of opposition parties in Turkey also condemned the raid on Turkish ships. The leader of [[Nationalist Movement Party|MHP]], [[Devlet Bahçeli]], said the attack was an aggression that should be never accepted by the Turkish nation.<ref name="bahceli">{{cite news|title=Bahçeli: Saldırı Türk milletine açık düşmanlıktır|publisher=[[NTV (Turkey)|NTV MSNBC]]|date=1 June 2010|url=http://www.ntvmsnbc.com/id/25101640/}}</ref>
[[Kemal Kılıçdaroğlu]], chairman of the [[Republican People's Party (Turkey)|Republican People's Party]] (CHP), supported Turkish government's efforts for a UN Security Council resolution to condemn Israeli government<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.todayszaman.com/tz-web/mobile.do?load=wapDetay&link=212535 |title=Today's Zaman Mobile Edition |newspaper=[[Today's Zaman]] |accessdate=27 March 2011}}{{dead link|date=August 2016}}</ref> and he said "We said we have given our support to the prime minister, as he said the attacks would not be left without a response. We said the CHP would support solutions which are concordant with our national interests."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.todayszaman.com/tz-web/news-212572-103-chp-to-present-parliament-motion-on-govt-actions-over-israeli-raid.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121005194721/http://www.todayszaman.com/tz-web/news-212572-103-chp-to-present-parliament-motion-on-govt-actions-over-israeli-raid.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=5 October 2012 |title=CHP to present Parliament motion on gov't actions over Israeli raid |newspaper=[[Today's Zaman]] |date=9 June 2010 |accessdate=27 March 2011}}</ref> However, he also criticized the Turkish government and told Turkish television, "The European Union and the United States consider Hamas a terror organization. We must be careful." He demanded that the government release communications with Israel prior to the incident, suggesting it allowed the flotilla to proceed despite knowing that violence was likely.<ref name="Benhorin">{{cite news |last=Benhorin |first=Yitzhak |title=Criticism in Turkey: Erdogan knew Gaza sail would be violent |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/Ext/Comp/ArticleLayout/CdaArticlePrintPreview/1,2506,L-3902451,00.html |publisher=[[Ynetnews]] |date=9 June 2010 |accessdate=19 June 2010}}</ref> Erdogan dismissed Kılıçdaroğlu as an Israeli "advocate" after Kılıçdaroğlu recited Torah's the eighth commandment, which says 'Do not steal' and the ninth commandment says 'Do not lie'.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.todayszaman.com/tz-web/news-212366-pm-lashes-out-at-aqua-aquaisrael-kilicdaroglu-in-speech.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121005195411/http://www.todayszaman.com/tz-web/news-212366-pm-lashes-out-at-aqua-aquaisrael-kilicdaroglu-in-speech.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=5 October 2012 |title=PM lashes out at Israel, Kılıçdaroğlu in speech |newspaper=[[Today's Zaman]] |date=7 June 2010 |accessdate=27 March 2011}}</ref>
== Arab League == {{Flag|Arab League}} called an emergency meeting on 1 June to discuss what it called Israel's "terrorist act" against the flotilla.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/world/middle_east/10196585.stm |title=LIVE: Israeli raid on Gaza flotilla |publisher=[[BBC News]] |date=31 May 2010 |accessdate=31 May 2010}}</ref> Secretary General of the Arab League, [[Amr Moussa]], stated, "we condemn this crime, taken against a humanitarian mission and people. They were trying to help people. They were not on a military mission. Everyone should condemn this."<ref name="arableague">{{cite news|url=http://www.kuwaittimes.net/read_news.php?newsid=OTE2NTM1NzIw |title=World shocked, outraged at raid |work=[[Kuwait Times]] |date=1 June 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110617014202/http://www.kuwaittimes.net/read_news.php?newsid=OTE2NTM1NzIw |archivedate=17 June 2011 |df= }}</ref> * {{flagicon|Palestinian Authority}} [[Palestinian Authority]] president, and [[Chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organisation]] ([[Palestine Liberation Organisation|PLO]]) since 11 November 2004, [[Mahmoud Abbas]] said, "Israel has committed a massacre,"<ref>[http://www.haaretz.com/news/diplomacy-defense/abbas-israel-has-committed-a-massacre-on-the-gaza-flotilla-1.293186?localLinksEnabled=false "Abbas: Israel has committed a massacre on the Gaza flotilla"]. ''[[Haaretz]]''.</ref> and declared a three-day [[state of mourning]]. Palestinian government official [[Mustafa Barghouti]] stated that Israel's actions would lead to the [[Economic and political boycotts of Israel|international boycott]] growing in strength.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3896805,00.html |title=Fatah official: Israel world's most despicable country |publisher=[[Ynetnews]] |date=31 May 2010 |accessdate=31 May 2010}}</ref> [[Salam Fayyad]] said "Israel went beyond all that could be expected. / This [attack] is a transgression against all international covenants and norms and it must be confronted by all international forums."<ref name="aljaz"/> **[[Hamas]] spokesman [[Sami Abu Zuhri]] said, "We call on all Arabs and Muslims to rise up in front of Zionist embassies across the whole world."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dawn.com/wps/wcm/connect/dawn-content-library/dawn/news/world/04-gaza-flotilla-casualties-qs-01|title=At least 10 dead as Israel forces storm Gaza aid boat|date=31 May 2010|newspaper=[[Dawn (newspaper)|Dawn]] |accessdate=31 May 2010}}</ref> *{{flagicon|Algeria}} Algeria condemned "in the strongest terms" the Israeli onslaught against the fleet of international aid for Gaza and requested a "strong and unanimous" response from the international community. *{{flagicon|Bahrain}} The government of Bahrain stated that it "strongly condemns the Israeli navy's barbaric attack on the aid flotilla in international waters, an attack which caused the deaths of many innocent victims. The Israeli use of force against civilians, including women, children and elders from several countries who sought to provide humanitarian aid to those people besieged in the Gaza Strip, must be condemned, is unacceptable, and is contrary to the basic laws and standards governing international waters."<ref>[http://english.bna.bh/?ID=87534 "Bahrain condemns the Israeli barbaric attack"]{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, [[Bahrain News Agency]], 31 May 2010</ref> *{{flagicon|Comoros}} The Consulate of The Comoros in Istanbul condemned the raid.<ref>{{cite news |title=İsrail ‘uluslararası suları’ kabul etti |newspaper=[[Hürriyet]] |url=http://www.hurriyet.com.tr/dunya/14896132.asp |date=1 June 2010}}</ref> *{{flagicon|Djibouti}} At the UN [[Human Rights Council]], [[Mohammed Siad Doualeh]] of Djibouti expressed deep concern over the killings<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.reliefweb.int/rw/rwb.nsf/db900SID/EGUA-85ZQVB?OpenDocument |title=Human Rights Council holds urgent debate on raid by Israeli Defence Forces on the flotilla carrying humanitarian aid for Gaza |date=6 January 2010 |publisher=[[ReliefWeb]] |accessdate=6 January 2010}}</ref> *{{flagicon|Egypt}} The Egyptian President [[Hosni Mubarak]] denounced Israel's use of "excessive and unjustified force" while the Foreign Ministry summoned the Israeli ambassador to express its condemnation.<ref name="arableague" /> The Egyptian President also ordered the opening of the Egyptian border to Gaza on Tuesday to allow humanitarian and medical aid into the Gaza Strip<ref>[http://www.english.rfi.fr/africa/20100601-egypt-opens-gaza-border-israel-kills-five-palestinians "Egypt opens Gaza border, Israel kills five Palestinians"], [[Radio France Internationale]], 1 June 2006</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Ashraf Sweilam |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5ioi_0jtO9RjMwPNRoXNCndRPRq3gD9G31JJG0 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100605161929/http://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5ioi_0jtO9RjMwPNRoXNCndRPRq3gD9G31JJG0 |dead-url=yes |archive-date= 5 June 2010 |publisher=[[Associated Press]] |title=Gazans cross border after Egypt lifts blockade |accessdate=2 June 2010 |df= }}</ref> *{{flagicon|Iraq}} An Iraqi government official, MP [[Khairallah al-Basri]] (a member of current premier [[Nouri al-Maliki]]'s [[State of Law Coalition]]), condemned the attack and described it as a "new humanitarian disaster", as well as, "a violation of human rights and a breach of international standards and norms".<ref>[http://www.earthtimes.org/articles/show/326401,attack-on-gaza-flotilla-humanitarian-disaster-says-iraq-official.html "Attack on Gaza flotilla 'humanitarian disaster', says Iraq official"], Earth Times, Deutsche Presse Agentur, 31 May 2010.{{dead link|date=August 2016}}</ref> *{{flagicon|Jordan}} The Jordanian government called the raid a "heinous crime". Minister of Communication and Media Affairs [[Nabil al-Sharif]] called the Israeli action an "ugly, unacceptable crime" and said that Jordan held Israel "completely accountable and responsible for any harm caused to the Jordanians on board".<ref name="alj-blog"/> *{{flagicon|Kuwait}} [[Kuwait National Assembly]] Speaker [[Jassem Al-Kharafi|Jassem Mohammad Al-Kharafi]] condemned the "heinous" Israeli attack on the convoy. He urged the United Nations to ensure the safety of those on board the convoy and to lift the blockade of Gaza.<ref>[http://www.menafn.com/qn_news_story_s.asp?StoryId=1093340677 "Kuwaiti Parliament condemns Israeli attack on Freedom Flotilla"], Middle East North Africa Financial Network, Kuwait News Agency, 31 May 2010.{{dead link|date=August 2016}}</ref> The Kuwaiti parliament has called an emergency session to discuss the attack.<ref name="alj-blog"/> *{{flagicon|Lebanon}} [[Saad Hariri]], the Prime Minister of Lebanon, said, "The Israeli attack on the aid convoy is a dangerous and crazy step that will exacerbate tensions in the region. Lebanon firmly denounces this attack and calls on the international community, notably major powers ... to take action in order to end this continued violation of human rights and threat to international peace."<ref name="alj-blog"/> **The Lebanese [[opposition party]] and paramilitary group [[Hezbollah]] issued a statement denouncing the "horrible terrorist crime committed by the Zionist occupation forces against innocent civilians on a human[e] mission to express solidarity with the Palestinians besieged in the Gaza strip". Adding that this was apparently proof of the "inherent evil in [[Zionist]]s which targets all human beings regardless of their confession and race as long as they're ready to stand by righteousness in the face of the persistent Zionist terrorism against the Palestinians". And, "this atrocious crime is the materialization of the inherent force of tyranny which has escalated in the past years due to the unlimited Western support to the Zionist scheme, and due to the wrong political bargaining of some Arab regimes."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.almanar.com.lb/newssite/NewsDetails.aspx?id=139872&language=en |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100531182539/http://www.almanar.com.lb/NewsSite/NewsDetails.aspx?id=139872&language=en |dead-url=yes |archive-date=31 May 2010 |title=Hezbollah: World Should Reject Oppression, Cut Ties with Israel 31/05/2010 |publisher=Al-Manar |accessdate=2 June 2010}}</ref> *{{flagicon|Mauritania}} Mauritania Ministry of Foreign Affairs issued a statement "strongly" condemning the Israeli attack, calling it a "cowardly act, a clear defiance to the international community and the continuing rejection of Israel to peace and coexistance". It urged the international community "to intervene to clarify this hideous crime, end Israel occupation in all Arab territories and stop the blockade on Gaza".<ref>[http://www.abc.es/agencias/noticia.asp?noticia=403413 "Mauritania califica el ataque israelí de 'desafío a comunidad internacional'"] (in Spanish), [[ABC (newspaper)|ABC]], Agencia [[EFE]], 31 May 2010</ref> *{{flagicon|Morocco}} Moroccan Foreign Minister [[Taieb Fassi Fihri]] stated, "the Kingdom of Morocco strongly denounces the disgraceful attack of Israel against the humanitarian convoy en route to Gaza."<ref>[http://www.aufaitmaroc.com/actualites/aujourd-hui/2010/5/31/flottille-le-maroc-denonce-lignoble-attaque-israelienne-ministre "Flottille: le Maroc dénonce 'l'ignoble attaque israélienne' (ministre)"] (in French), aufait Maroc, 1 June 2010 {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707190913/http://www.aufaitmaroc.com/actualites/aujourd-hui/2010/5/31/flottille-le-maroc-denonce-lignoble-attaque-israelienne-ministre |date= 7 July 2011 }}</ref> *{{flagicon|Oman}} Oman stated that the attack "violates international law".<ref>W. G. Dunlop, [https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jTqPcDxEblk8X7_jF7VtxBDBS5-A "Arabs furious over deadly Israel raid, demand UN action"], AFP, 31 May 2010 {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100603214258/http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jTqPcDxEblk8X7_jF7VtxBDBS5-A |date= 3 June 2010 }}</ref> *{{flagicon|Qatar}} Qatari [[Emir]] [[Sheikh Hamad bin Khalifa Al-Thani]] condemned Israel's deadly raid against a Gaza-bound aid flotilla, branding it an "act of piracy".<ref>[http://www.gulf-times.com/site/topics/article.asp?cu_no=2&item_no=365293&version=1&template_id=57&parent_id=56 "Qatar condemns Israel"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110606194852/http://www.gulf-times.com/site/topics/article.asp?cu_no=2&item_no=365293&version=1&template_id=57&parent_id=56 |date=6 June 2011 }}, [[Gulf Times]], 1 June 2010</ref> At the Doha Forum 2010, he stated "The crime perpetrated this morning against civilians supporting the Palestinians reminds us of the unjust siege, the open, bleeding wound in the Strip. And all those who speak for freedom, justice and democracy must do something now to break the siege imposed on the Gaza Strip so that the blood of these free people will not go in vain. This is a message to the Arab countries that now face the moment of truth." He said the blockade was imposed because "the people of Gaza practised their democratic right in the elections." The Prime Minister and Foreign Minister, Sheikh [[Hamad bin Jassem bin Jabr Al Thani]], lauded the call by the Emir and reiterated Qatar's condemnation of the Israeli assault. He called the attack a premeditated assault on innocent people and a flagrant breach of international law and conventions. Asking "who would pay for the blood of those who were killed yesterday", while holding the international community responsible for tolerating such "barbaric practices" that could have grave repercussions for the region. He also expressed Qatar's solidarity with Turkey and stand supporting justice, though he expressed doubt over whether the Arab peace initiative would now go ahead with indirect and direct negotiations after "Israel was opposing peace."<ref>{{cite news |date=1 June 2010 |url=http://www.thepeninsulaqatar.com/qatar/5114-emir-calls-on-world-to-break-gaza-siege.html |title=Emir calls on world to break Gaza siege |newspaper=[[The Peninsula (newspaper)|The Peninsula]] |accessdate=2 June 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120913212410/http://www.thepeninsulaqatar.com/qatar/5114-emir-calls-on-world-to-break-gaza-siege.html |archivedate=13 September 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> <!--Discuss the notability of this cartoon at [[Talk:Reactions to the Gaza flotilla raid#A work by a Brasilian Cartoonist]] before edit warring.-->[[File:Ship to Gaza by Latuff.gif|right|thumb| A cartoon by Carlos Latuff depicting the Gaza flotilla raid. It was published in ''[[Arab News]]''.<ref>{{cite news |newspaper=Arab News |date=4 June 2010 |title=Israel's dastardly attack}} via {{cite web |author=Latuff2 |title=Octopus cartoon in Arabnews |publisher=Deviant Art |url=http://latuff2.deviantart.com/art/Octopus-cartoon-in-Arabnews-166740956}}</ref>]] *{{flagicon|Saudi Arabia}} Saudi Arabian [[King Abdullah bin Abdulaziz Al Saud]] chaired a Saudi Cabinet session that "denounced and condemned the massacre committed" and "described the attack as aggressive and reflects Israel's inhuman practices, flagrant defiance of the whole world and international law, insistence to starve the Palestinian people and prevent all kinds of humanitarian relief, and indulgence in killing innocent people".<ref>[http://www.qnaol.net/QNAEn/News_bulletin/News/Pages/10-05-31-2034_116_0081.aspx "Saudi Arabia Denounce Massacre Committed By Israel"]{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, [[Qatar News Agency]], 1 June 2010</ref> *{{flagicon|Sudan}} The Sudanese Ministry of Foreign Affairs issued a statement saying the "Sudan government, strongly condemning the repeated Israeli crimes, calls on the international community, including governments, organizations and peoples, to come together, more than [at] any time before, against the state of the Zionist enemy and to show the real power of law to prevent Israel from what is committing of crimes against humanity and genocide against the Palestinian people".<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/2010-05/31/c_13326016.htm |title=Sudan condemns Israeli attack on Freedom Flotilla |publisher=[[Xinhua News Agency]] |accessdate=2 June 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100605104705/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/2010-05/31/c_13326016.htm |archivedate=5 June 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The [[National Assembly of Sudan|National Assembly]] of Sudan issued a statement saying "the parliament condemns the Israeli attack against international activists who were trying to deliver food for the civilians in Gaza," adding "the attack constitutes a major crime against civilians and should be condemned". The Sudanese Ministry of Foreign Affairs issued a statement on behalf of the government, saying it was "strongly condemning the repeated Israeli crimes" and "calls on the international community, including governments, organizations and peoples, to come together, more than any time before" to show "the real power of law" to stop the Israeli regime from committing what it described as "crimes against humanity and genocide against the Palestinian people". It called on the international community to unite to end Israel's "enjoy[ment of] protection and support of influential countries" and what it sees as "exposed silence on the part of the United Nations".<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/2010-05/31/c_13326016.htm |title=Sudan condemns Israeli attack on Freedom Flotilla |publisher=[[Xinhua News Agency]] |date=31 May 2010 |accessdate=31 May 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100605104705/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/2010-05/31/c_13326016.htm |archivedate=5 June 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> *{{flagicon|Syria}} Syrian [[Foreign Ministry]] issued a statement condemning Israeli assault on the Gaza-bound international aid flotilla and called it a "bloody and heinous piracy crime committed by Israel in the Mediterranean international water".<ref>[http://www.istockanalyst.com/article/viewiStockNews/articleid/4166013 "Syria condemns Israeli assault on Gaza aid convoy"], iStockAnalyst, 31 May 2010 {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120322114105/http://www.istockanalyst.com/article/viewiStockNews/articleid/4166013 |date=22 March 2012 }}</ref> The Syrian government has called a meeting of the [[Arab League]] to discuss the attack.<ref name="alj-blog"/> *{{flagicon|Tunisia}} The Foreign Affairs Ministry of Tunisia issued a statement saying "While reiterating its condemnation of all forms of collective punishment, Tunisia urges the international community, particularly influential forces to immediately intervene to lift the unjust blockade imposed on the Palestinian people in Gaza and to put an end to their suffering." Tunisia added that it was "reaffirm[ing] its rejection of these hostile practices that are an affront to the international community and a violation of agreements and international and humanitarian resolutions, which threaten to further complicate the situation in the region and undermine any hope of peace".<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.tunisiaonlinenews.com/?p=40182 |title=Tunisia condemns Israeli attack against Gaza humanitarian aid flotilla |newspaper=[[Tunisia News]] |date=31 May 2010 |accessdate=31 May 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100601213328/http://www.tunisiaonlinenews.com/?p=40182 |archivedate=1 June 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> *{{flagicon|United Arab Emirates}} United Arab Emirates condemned Israel's violent attack on the Freedom Flotilla. [[Shaikh Abdullah]] said, "the attack on civilians traversing across the sea to deliver aid to the Palestinian people strongly defied international laws" and called for a United Nations led investigation.<ref>[http://gulfnews.com/news/gulf/uae/government/uae-condemns-freedom-flotilla-attack-1.634924 "UAE condemns Freedom Flotilla attack"], ''[[Gulf News]]'', 31 May 2010</ref> *{{flagicon|Yemen}} The [[Assembly of Representatives of Yemen|Parliament]] of Yemen strongly condemned the Israeli attack and demanded for "an Islamic army to encounter the Israeli arrogance".<ref>[http://www.newsyemen.net/en/view_news.asp?sub_no=3_2010_05_31_40105 "Yemen denounces Israeli attack on Gaza flotilla, calls for sending 'Islamic army'"], News Yemen, 31 May 2010 {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100605090408/http://newsyemen.net/en/view_news.asp?sub_no=3_2010_05_31_40105 |date= 5 June 2010 }}</ref>
In a joint-statement, Syrian President Bashar al—Assad and Lebanese Prime Minister Saad Hariri "condemn[ed] the heinous crime committed by Israel through the brutal attacks on unarmed civilians on board the Freedom Flotilla". While warning that Israel's "violations of basic humanitarian norms and international laws threatens to plunge the Middle East into a war which will not only affect the region".<ref>{{cite news|author=DPA |url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/international/article442867.ece |title=Syria, Lebanon say flotilla attack can lead to war |newspaper=[[The Hindu]] |date=29 May 2010 |location=Chennai, India |accessdate=2 June 2010}}</ref> After reconfirming bonds with Turkey and harshly criticizing the Israeli siege, al-Assad joint Ergodan in proposing a new initiative aimed at having the blockade on Gaza lifted "once and for all". His plan involved "a number of political ideas for regional and international activity aimed at lifting the siege". [[Foreign relations of Qatar|Qatar]] is slated to take part in the initiative's implementation.<ref>[http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3902100,00.html "Syria, Turkey to cooperate to remove Gaza siege"]. [[Ynetnews]] (20 June 1995).</ref> At the conference, Erdogan urged Arab nations to unite and step-up efforts to end Israel's blockade on the Gaza Strip. He said "Are we going to remain silent over the murder of nine people? We can't turn a blind eye to this banditry in international waters. This can't continue as it is. Peace and stability will not come to the region as long as the blockade of Gaza persists. Painful experience has made it clear that no [regional] country will fully achieve prosperity and security as long as the Palestinian-Israeli conflict remains unresolved."<ref>[http://english.aljazeera.net/news/europe/2010/06/2010610131536205769.html "Israel dominates Turkey-Arab forum"]. [[Al Jazeera English]] (10 June 2010).</ref>
==Africa== *[[African Union]] condemned Israel for the killings.<ref>Alex Tembel (1 December 2000) [https://web.archive.org/web/20100606231956/http://www.afriquejet.com/news/africa-news/african-union-wants-israeli-attack-on-gaza-aid-convoy-probed-2010060150191.html "African Union wants Israeli attack on Gaza aid convoy probed"] </ref> *{{flagicon|Gabon}} The representative of Gabon at the UN Security Council expressed his shock at the events. He further called upon Israel to lift the blockade of Gaza, and called all parties to refrain from violence.<ref name=UNSC/> *{{flagicon|Kenya}} The Kenyan government issued a statement condemning the killing of nine activists as "grossly callous and a brazen violation of international law".<ref>[http://www.theeastafrican.co.ke/news/-/2558/930300/-/pe18tiz/-/index.html "Kenya government condemns Israel attack on Gaza-bound ships"]. ''[[The EastAfrican]]''.</ref> *{{flagicon|SADR}} The government of the Sahrawi Arab Democratic Republic condemned "in the strongest terms the abject and shameful attack of the Israeli army against the Flotilla of Freedom. By carrying out the bombing of a fleet carrying humanitarian aid to the people of Gaza, deprived of everything including medication, Israel commits an unforgivable act contrary to international law and the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, which guarantees the protection of citizens around the world," the statement added.<ref>[http://www.spsrasd.info/en/detail.php?id=11858 "SADR strongly condemns Israel's raid on flotilla of Gaza-bound aid ships"]{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} [[Sahara Press Service]], 1 June 2010. Retrieved 23 January 2011.</ref> *{{flagicon|South Africa}} South Africa [[Department of International Relations and Cooperation (South Africa)|Foreign Ministry]] issued a statement "strongly condemning all military aggression by Israel against innocent civilians, including those in the occupied West Bank and Gaza".<ref>[http://www.dfa.gov.za/docs/2010/isra0531.html "South Africa condemns the Israeli Attacks on Aid Ships to Gaza"], [[Department of International Relations and Cooperation]], 31 May 2010</ref> On 3 June, South Africa recalled its ambassador from Israel, and the Israeli ambassador was summoned to the Foreign Ministry for a reprimand.<ref name="S Africa recalls Israel ambassador"/><ref>{{cite news |last=Mizroch |first=Amir |url=http://www.jpost.com/International/Article.aspx?id=177408 |title=South Africa recalls its ambassador |work=[[The Jerusalem Post]] |accessdate=12 May 2012}}</ref>
==Americas== ;{{Flag|Organization of American States}} The [[Secretary General of the Organization of American States|Secretary General]] of the [[Organization of American States]] said "Nothing can justify excessive use of military force to attack, with serious loss of human lives, to a disarmed civil convoy." Also he warned of a violence increase risk in the Middle East, Mr. [[José Miguel Insulza]] asked "to avoid actions which can means to increase the situation that, once again, threatens seriously the peace process in the Middle East".<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.rpp.com.pe/2010-05-31-oea-censura-ataque-de-israel-a-flotilla-humanitaria-noticia_268974.html |title=OEA censura ataque de Israel a flotilla humanitaria |publisher=[[Radio Programas del Perú]] |accessdate=2 June 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100603011651/http://www.rpp.com.pe/2010-05-31-oea-censura-ataque-de-israel-a-flotilla-humanitaria-noticia_268974.html |archivedate=3 June 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> *{{flagicon|Argentina}} Argentina's [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs, International Trade and Worship|Foreign Affairs Ministry]] (''Cancillería'') issued a statement condemning the attack by Israeli forces, called for a full investigation and deeply regretted the loss of human lives. It also asked for an immediate stop to acts of violence in the area, and the lifting of the blockade.<ref>[http://www.losandes.com.ar/notas/2010/5/31/un-493164.asp "Rechazo del Gobierno argentino"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110609072814/http://www.losandes.com.ar/notas/2010/5/31/un-493164.asp |date=9 June 2011 }} (in Spanish), ''[[Los Andes (Argentine newspaper)|Los Andes]]'' 31 May 2010</ref> *{{flagicon|Bolivia}} Bolivia [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Religion (Bolivia)|Ministry of Foreign Affairs]] issued a statement calling the attack "atrocious", adding that the actions were a flagrant violation of international law and called for an investigation.<ref>[http://www.rree.gov.bo/webmre/prensa.aspx?pagina=np24.htm&ruta=notasprensa/2010/2010_mayo/ "Comunicado del Gobierno Boliviano en Respuesta al Ataque por el Ejército Israelí"]{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} (in Spanish), Press Release, Bolivia Government, 31 May 2010</ref> *{{flagicon|Brazil}} Brazil's [[Ministry of External Relations (Brazil)|Ministry of External Relations]] issued a statement strongly condemning the Israeli action, calling for an independent investigation and the end of the blockade of the Gaza Strip. Brazil also expressed deep concern over the well-being of one of its citizens, [[Iara Lee]], that was on board the flotilla. They further said that they had instructed the Permanent Representative of Brazil to the United Nations to fully support an emergency meeting of the United Nations Security Council to discuss the Israeli military action,<ref>[http://www.itamaraty.gov.br/sala-de-imprensa/notas-a-imprensa/ataque-israelense-a-201cflotilha-da-liberdade201d "Note 349 – Israeli flotilla attack"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716154144/http://www.itamaraty.gov.br/sala-de-imprensa/notas-a-imprensa/ataque-israelense-a-201cflotilha-da-liberdade201d |date=16 July 2011 }} [[Ministry of External Relations (Brazil)|Ministry of External Relations of Brazil]]. Retrieved on 2010-05-31. {{pt icon}}</ref> and that the Ambassador of Israel in Brasília had been summoned to explain the events.<ref>{{cite news|title=Brazil summons Israeli ambassador over IDF raid|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3897038,00.html|publisher=[[Ynetnews]]|date=31 May 2010}}</ref> *{{flagicon|Canada}} The Canadian [[Office of the Prime Minister (Canada)|prime minister's office]] released a statement saying it "deeply regrets" the loss of life in the Israeli raid on an aid flotilla sailing to the blockaded Gaza Strip and that they "... are currently looking for more information in order to shed light on what exactly happened".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/world/story/2010/05/31/israel-gaza-aid-death.html |title=Zardari Israel storms Gaza-bound aid ships |publisher=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]] |date=31 May 2010 |accessdate=31 May 2010}}</ref> The [[Edmonton Journal]] asserted its view that Canada's "cautious" approach was the right one as "tragedies involving loss of life in the Middle East invariably provoke reflexive responses from opposing camps". This was despite the arrest of Canadian Kevin Neish.<ref>{{cite news |date=1 June 2010 |url=http://www.edmontonjournal.com/news/Harper+caution+best+reaction/3095691/story.html |title=Harper's caution best reaction |newspaper=[[Edmonton Journal]] |accessdate=2 June 2010 }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> *{{flagicon|Chile}} The Chilean [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Chile)|Foreign Ministry]] said in a statement, "Chile condemns the use of the forces in any form."<ref>[http://english.peopledaily.com.cn/90001/90777/90852/7006899.html "Latin American countries condemn Israeli attack against humanitarian aid ship"], [[People's Daily]] Online, [[Xinhua News Agency]], 31 May 2009</ref> Chilean [[Senate of Chile|Senator]] Alejandro Navarro, who was scheduled to be aboard the Gaza aid convoy, denounced the attack as "cowardly and disproportionate against unarmed civilians".<ref>[http://www.mercuriovalpo.cl/prontus4_noticias/site/artic/20100531/pags/20100531104556.html "Senador Navarro dice que pudo morir en ataque israelí a flota humanitaria"] (in Spanish), ''[[El Mercurio de Valparaíso]]'', 31 May 2010.</ref> He further stated that Chile "condemns Israel and this event will have multilateral consequences because it set a serious precedent". *{{flagicon|Ecuador}} Ecuador President [[Rafael Correa]] said he recalled his ambassador to Israel for consultations after which the Ecuadorian Foreign Ministry said the ambassador would leave Tel Aviv immediately "as an act of protest against the attack which left civilians killed and injured".<ref>[http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3898523,00.html "Ecuador recalls envoy; Chavez: Israel a murderer"], [[Ynetnews]], 3 June 2010</ref> *{{flagicon|Mexico}} Mexico [[Secretariat of Foreign Affairs (Mexico)|Secretariat of Foreign Affairs]] issued a statement "strongly condemning the Israeli attack on civilian vessels in international waters carrying humanitarian aid". It called for a full investigation.<ref>[http://www.informador.com.mx/mexico/2010/205905/6/mexico-condena-energicamente-ataque-israeli-a-flotilla-humanitaria.htm "México condena 'enérgicamente' ataque israelí a flotilla humanitaria"] (in Spanish), ''[[El Informador (Mexico)|El Informador]]'', 31 May 2010</ref> *{{flagicon|Nicaragua}} The Nicaraguan [[President of Nicaragua|government]] called the Israeli actions "a clear violation of humanitarian and international law", and suspended diplomatic ties with Israel in protest of the raid.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/2010-06/02/c_13328920.htm |title=Nicaragua suspends diplomatic ties with Israel |publisher=[[Xinhua News Agency]] |date=2 June 2010 |accessdate=12 May 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121106121010/http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/world/2010-06/02/c_13328920.htm |archivedate=6 November 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> *{{flagicon|Paraguay}} Paraguay Foreign Affairs Ministry issued a statement "condemning" and "strongly rejecting" the Israeli attack on the convoy and supported the United Nations' call for a full investigation.<ref>[http://www.lanacion.com.py/noticias_um-309384.htm "Paraguay 'rechaza' y 'condena' ataque israelí a convoy humanitario"]{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} (in Spanish), ''[[La Nación (Paraguay)|La Nación]]'', AFP, 31 May 2010</ref> *{{flagicon|Peru}} Peruvian [[Ministry of Foreign Relations (Peru)|Foreign Affairs Ministry]] issued a statement condemning Israeli violent attack on the human assistance convoy. Peru disapproves the use of military force based on international rights principles and calls for a full investigation. Peruvian government exhorts to restore dialogue and negotiation in order to reach permanent peace agreements and made an urgent call to the Government of Israel to allow the free flow of humanitarian aid to the people in Gaza Strip<ref>[http://www.rree.gob.pe/portal/boletinInf.nsf/mrealdia/12B0273051E9D49005257735004B7932?OpenDocument "Official notice 002- 10"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100609020730/http://www.rree.gob.pe/portal/boletinInf.nsf/mrealdia/12B0273051E9D49005257735004B7932?OpenDocument |date=9 June 2010 }} (in Spanish), [[Ministry of Foreign Relations (Peru)|Foreign Affairs Ministry]], 1 June 2010</ref> *{{flagicon|USA}} The United States Secretary of State [[Hillary Clinton]] said, "United States supports the United Nations Security Council's condemnation of the acts leading to this tragedy, and we urge Israel to permit full consular access to the individuals involved, and to allow the countries concerned to retrieve their deceased and wounded immediately. We support in the strongest terms the Security Council's call for a prompt, impartial, credible, and transparent investigation."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/video/#/video/politics/2010/06/01/bts.clinton.israel.gaza.flotilla.cnn?hpt=T1 |title=U.S. Condemns Israel Flotilla Raid |publisher=[[CNN]] |date=16 July 2010 |accessdate=12 May 2012}}</ref> A [[White House]] spokesman cautiously said that the United States "deeply regrets the loss of life and injuries sustained, and is currently working to understand the circumstances surrounding this tragedy".<ref name="alj-blog" /><ref>{{Cite news |first=Glenn |last=Greenwald |date=31 May 2010 |title=Israel attacks aid ship, kills at least 10 civilians |url=http://www.salon.com/news/opinion/glenn_greenwald/2010/05/31/israel/index.html#postid-updateA6|publisher=[[Salon (website)|Salon]] |accessdate=31 May 2010}}</ref> President Barack Obama told his counterpart Benjamin Netanyahu that he deeply regretted the loss of life in the Israeli raid urged him to quickly get to the bottom of the incident. The White House summarized the President's conversation saying "The president expressed deep regret at the loss of life in today's incident, and concern for the wounded."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/diplomacy-defense/obama-withholds-condemnation-of-gaza-flotilla-clashes-calls-for-clarification-of-facts-1.293387|title=Obama withholds condemnation of Gaza flotilla clashes, calls for clarification of 'facts' |work=[[Haaretz]] |location=Israel |accessdate=2 June 2010}}</ref> In the Senate, Majority Leader [[Harry Reid]] and Minority Leader [[Mitch McConnell]] co-authored a letter signed by 85 other senators arguing for the legality of the blockade and the raid and calling on the President to support Israel.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://thehill.com/blogs/blog-briefing-room/news/105093-87-senators-defend-israel-in-flotilla-incident?page=1|last=Zimmermann|first=Eric|date=23 June 2010|newspaper=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]]|title=Reid and McConnell lead letter to Obama defending Israel in flotilla incident}}</ref> Rep. Anthony Weiner of the U.S. congress criticized the flotilla, saying that it had was supported "by some of the worst enemies of peace in that region, and some of the worst enemies, quite literally, not only of Israel, but of the United States as well. And I mean Turkey, Iran, Hamas. These are not entities that were looking for some peaceful resolution here."<ref name="Hill">{{cite news |last=Bogardus|first=Kevin|title=Ally Turkey comes under increasing criticism from some lawmakers|url=http://thehill.com/homenews/house/102891-turkey-alliance-comes-under-increasing-criticism-from-lawmakers|newspaper=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]] |accessdate=19 June 2010}}</ref> "The complicity of Turkey in launching a flotilla to challenge the blockade in Gaza, the ensuing violence that occurred, the grievous loss of life is deeply troubling to those of us who have supported the U.S.-Turkish alliance in the past," Rep. Mike Pence said on the House floor. "Turkey needs to decide whether its present course is in its long-term interests, but America will stand with Israel."<ref name="Hill"/> In an interview with [[Charlie Rose]], Vice President [[Joe Biden]] defended Israel's decision to intercept the pro-Palestinian flotilla bringing humanitarian aid to the coastal territory, but did not defend the Israel Navy raid itself. He stated, "you can argue whether Israel should have dropped people onto that ship or not[, but Israel] has a right to know whether or not arms are being smuggled in."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/diplomacy-defense/biden-israel-right-to-stop-gaza-flotilla-from-breaking-blockade-1.293833| title=Biden: Israel right to stop Gaza flotilla from breaking blockade |work=[[Haaretz]] |location=Israel |accessdate=2 June 2010}}</ref> Mike Hammer, a spokesperson for the [[United States National Security Council|National Security Council]], said: "The current arrangements are unsustainable and must be changed."<ref name="Al Jazeera Tails">{{cite news|publisher=[[Al Jazeera English]]|title=Israel navy tails Gaza aid ship|date=5 June 2010|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2010/06/201064235620154213.html|accessdate=5 June 2010}}</ref> The city of San Francisco's [[Board of Supervisors]] was considering a non-binding resolution introduced John Avalos and Sophie Maxwell calling for "condemning the Israel Defense Forces' military attack on the Freedom Flotilla", while also calling on the [[US Congress]] and Obama to continue working to bring peace and security to the Gaza region.<ref>Gordon, Rachel. (10 June 2010)[http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/blogs/cityinsider/detail?entry_id=65535#ixzz0qWL9Mg1C City Insider : Israeli flotilla raid lands on supervisors' radar]. ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]''.</ref> *{{flagicon|Uruguay}} Uruguay's Foreign Affairs Ministry condemned the Israeli navy's action, expressed sorrow for the loss of life and demanded a "quick independent investigation and called on the Israeli government for full cooperation".<ref>[http://www.prensa-latina.cu/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=193297&Itemid=1 "Gobierno uruguayo condena ataque israelí"] (in Spanish), [[Prensa Latina]], 31 May 2010</ref> The ministry has also expressed its solidarity with the families of the victims and is asking for the siege on Gaza to end.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.prensa-latina.cu/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=193297&Itemid=1 |title=Gobierno uruguayo condena ataque israelí |publisher=[[Prensa Latina]] |date=1 January 1970 |accessdate=12 May 2012}}</ref> *{{flagicon|Venezuela}} Venezuelan [[President of Venezuela|President]] [[Hugo Chavez]] condemned Israel's "attack on peace activists". He called the attack "an act of war undertaken by the Israeli army against defenseless civilians" who were trying to break through Israel's "criminal blockade".<ref>[http://www.presstv.ir/detail.aspx?id=128578&sectionid=351020704 "Israel committed an act of war"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100602090019/http://www.presstv.ir/detail.aspx?id=128578&sectionid=351020704 |date=2 June 2010 }}, [[Press TV]], 1 June 2010</ref> At a rally, Chavez described Israel as "cursed terrorist and murderous state" and further alleged "Israel is financing the Venezuelan opposition. There are even groups of Israeli terrorists, of the Mossad, who are after me trying to kill me."<ref>[http://www.jta.org/news/article/2010/06/06/2739462/venezuelas-chavez-attacks-israel-in-speech "Venezuela's Chavez attacks Israel in speech"], [[Jewish Telegraphic Agency]] (JTA), 8 June 2010.</ref>
;Non-OAS members *{{flagicon|Cuba}} The Cuban [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Cuba)|Ministry of Foreign Affairs]] condemned the Israeli action, calling it a "criminal attack" and expressed its "most energetic condemnation". Cuba calls for the lifting of the Gaza blockade and reaffirms its solidarity with the Palestinian people.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://america.cubaminrex.cu/English/Statements/Articulos/StatementsMINREX/2010/01-06-10.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100715225419/http://america.cubaminrex.cu/English/Statements/Articulos/StatementsMINREX/2010/01-06-10.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=15 July 2010 |title=Statement from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs on the Criminal Attack Perpetrated by Israel on the Humanitarian Flotilla |publisher=america.cubaminrex.cu |date=31 May 2010 |accessdate=1 June 2010}}</ref> Former Cuban President [[Fidel Castro]] condemned Israel's attack on the Freedom Flotilla as "Nazi fascist fury". Adding that the Israeli commandos who boarded the ships fired "frenetically" at the aid workers. he then asked "Is it possible [for Obama to be re-elected] without the Pentagon of ... Israel ... use nuclear weapons against Iran?"<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail.aspx?id=128842&sectionid=351020702 |title='Israeli attack was Nazi fascist fury' |publisher=[[Press TV]] |date=3 June 2010 |accessdate=3 June 2010}}</ref>
==Asia== *{{flagicon|Bangladesh}} Bangladesh's Ministry of Foreign Affairs stated, "Bangladesh is shocked and saddened at the unwarranted attack on unarmed civilians on board the ''Mavi Marmara'' on 31 May 2010, and the resultant loss of lives." The Ministry also said that Bangladesh expresses its profound condolences and sincerest sympathy to the bereaved families, and joins in prayer for the eternal peace of the departed souls. Bangladesh also called for collective international action to end the siege immediately and to allow the people of Palestine to return to normal life.<ref>{{cite news |author=Zhang Jin |url=http://english.cri.cn/6966/2010/06/01/1461s573834.htm |title=Bangladesh Condemns Israeli Attack on Freedom Flotilla |publisher=[[China Radio International]] |date=1 June 2010 |accessdate=2 June 2010}}</ref> *{{flagicon|Brunei}} Brunei [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Trade (Brunei)|Foreign Minister]] [[Pengiran Muda Mohamed Bolkiah]] condemn the recent Israeli raid on Gaza-bound Turkish aid ships. In a joint statement with other ministers of the second Asean-Gulf Cooperation Council (Asean-GCC), he condemn the act of violence in international waters and expressed condolences to the victims of the raid and expressed solidarity with the people and government of Turkey and other countries. The ministers also urged the immediate release of those who are still held hostage by the Israeli authorities and called for the removal of the Israeli blockade in accordance with the relevant UN Security Council resolutions, in particular [[United Nations Security Council Resolution 1860]]. With the recent raid, Israel has once again created additional hurdles to the Middle East peace process which is currently entering a critical phase with the launch of "proximity talks".
